The stock is safe, the CCP would be shooting themselves in the foot to destroy their best AMZN competitor in the next 5 years.

author: PlandomeProwler
body:
Just out on CLOV

Clover Health (CLOV) is joining other Medicare Advantage (MA) plans in offering a grocery benefit to its members, an option that was first made available by the U.S. Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) in 2018. 
Clover CEO Vivek Garipalli told Yahoo Finance the goal is to help alleviate health-determining factors, known in the industry as social determinants of health, which include access to healthy food.
Major MA players like Humana (HUM) and Centene (CNC) have already begun to offer the benefit, as have others in the past year.

Clover has calculated an annual benefit of between $300 to $500 per member, depending on the plan, which comes at no cost to plan members. Qualifying members are those with underlying conditions.

author: TheRandomnatrix
body:
Stay away from day trading. It's a nasty habit to pick up and most people aren't cut out for it. Swing tradings a lot less work and typically safer

My advice is:

* The best trading comes from companies that slowly go up long term, but trade "flat" over the medium term with stable tops and bottoms.  Amazon and mastercard are good examples of this right now. It's a common mistake to think that companies have to constantly be going up to make money, when the opposite couldn't be truer. You also can't go wrong with swing trading safer companies with lower volatility, especially when you're new. Those are the companies you can safely hold if things go south.

* Don't get married to a single stock. This is a rookie mistake. There's going to be plenty of moments where stocks just don't make sense to trade, typically when they're outside of a predictable trading range(such as breaking a support or resistance) or if it's just not at a good price within the trading range. Do not force trades that don't make sense because you think you need to trade constantly.

* Following that, sometimes you just have to say fuck it and take a stock out of your watchlist because it's no longer favorable to trade within your strategies. I just did that with HD and FB after their insane runups since I now have no idea what they'll be trading within and speculating that is a complete waste of my time for now. The market is always changing and favorable companies can and will become unfavorable.

* If you're trying to get 10% swings constantly you need to curb your expectations. 3-5% is much more reasonable and can be achieved faster as most stocks have +/- 1-3% volatility. Reliable profits always beat occasional large profits

author: QuestionablySensible
body:
I'm not sure how familiar you are with the solutions but I would disagree with that statement. They may be easily able to spread across different payment solutions but they will still need underlying payment infrastructure to get from A to B (or P2P, or B2C, or B2B).

The requirements for this infrastructure are quite high - not just hardware (although there is a difference in focus as transactions *cannot* be lost) but also in terms of regulatory oversight. You can't just start routing transactions without dealing with KYC (Know your customer) AMLA (Anti-Money Laundering) and other financial requirements. 

Visa and MasterCard aren't stupid. Their fees get complained about but they're juuuuust low enough that the investment to replace their payment infrastructure is not attractive. It doesn't mean that they cannot misstep or be challenged, but they have done a good job of keeping up with, and sometimes driving, the payments market.

author: sharist_DIY_bio
body: Because I get the science and have been a USGOV grantee, or paid techno-evangelist for many years in developing what we call "transitional" economies, for twenty years. NAT SEC determines critical roles, infrastructure, and resources, whether language or minerals, in our home grown knowledge base. That means they may determine there are no native born US citizens who speak a certain language. Imagine our dependence on translators in any conflict environment. They may determine we are fucked on cobalt if we want to build batteries. Their job is not actually to staff current conflicts, but to actually project, as far as reasonable, future conflicts and anticipate the need and staff it. They also will wish to staff folks who sow seeds to *avert conflict* and or stage preparedness for future conflicts, in a manner that shifts said conflict in their favor. Interestingly enough, I am American woman, and I abide by rule of law while promoting it overseas, as a service,very cheaply. It is my honor. Why? They don't pay me enough to be loyal. I am loyal because it is my honor and the fabric of my being. They chose me because they know for a fact that I am loyal. Sure, I'm gonna eat street meat in Beijing, savor Crickets on a stick in Burma fed to me by unemployed physicists, feel tanks in my sternum in Moscow in 1990-1991, get Jack Ma heads up from folks to whom I provided VPNS in 2000 in the PRD, 12 hours before BABA tanks. But, ultimately, I have never ever been told what to tell people on the ground when they drop me in country. I am a free agent with (as you may have noticed) every liberty in my free speech. I was allowed to go places in 'transition,' to help or provide tech and humanitarian aide, and I was taught better facility in languages to do so... NOT because I work for the US Gov, but because they vetted me and knew our interests coincided. I wanted the same things they did. It is fairly random. I have signed many agreements, to secure my language training in the many languages I deploy. Those agreements say I will drop everything and serve, if we ever declare war, as a translator. As long as they use plenty of swear words while at war, we should be ok. ;D lol.. I would have have dropped everything, anyway, to serve, so those agreements never bothered me one bit. Why do I like Ginkgo? Because it is in the best interest of global citizens and the USA to form both a biosecurity protocol, and deploy this new tech. It is simultaneously in the best interest of the planet to harness this technology and to have a measured democratic access to the power and promise Syn Bio holds, while sharing, with bio/cyber/controls for the public good. Ginkgo will never weaponize it. I'm banking on that. In the ecosystem I have studied, Zy, not so much. Ginkgo, yes. They will not weaponize it. I invest accordingly with my own eyes wide open. I think Ginkgo is the way to go. I am not paid to do so, but I do enjoy the favor of tax payer dollars to have become a polyglot and represent this technology in multiple languages in places you would most likely never travel of your volition. I do so willingly and with no coercion. I think it will be a breakthrough the likes of the Marshall Plan, following on the Covid catastrophe. I would like to see American democratic values adapt and once again become the shining light on the hill we once were. This pisses people off who have not traveled as widely as me and seen the poverty and potential in the rest of the world when they met young STEM kids abroad. I have very different reasons for making the Ginkgo play than you. You are a quant, I am a qual.

author: stuff-dat-roo
body:
Sure, that said:

- If you look at infection/death rate ratio in the UK it seems like we are getting significantly better at treating COVID cases. 

- The 40% headline number doesn’t consider population density/significance. In dense states like California, New York, and states in New England vaccination rates among 18+ are 70-85%. This trend is further exacerbated when you look at rural vs urban within states. These are the people who are most at risk to COVID spread, and also frankly those regions have a much larger impact on the US economy (said like a true NYer lols).

- The 40% also doesn’t consider at risk populations. As I mentioned, every single state has vaccinated 75%+ of its 65+ population. In states like MA, CA, NY, 85%+ of 65+ year olds are vaccinated. These are the people who are most likely to be affected by COVID.

We seem to be conflating “people might get sick” and “the stock market will crash”

| Square                      |   SQ   |  3,00% |
| Visa                        |    V   |  3,00% |

The weights are target weights, btw. I don't sell to get down to the target weight (except when there is massive growth in one of those; I reduced my holdings of SQ like this before, for example). Mostly, I keep the balance by contributing to those which are underweight, not selling the overweight winners. I consider virtually all of these as hold forever stocks, but I do occasionally switch them up (if it's a good time to sell, e.g. I can do that without capital gains tax - selling at a loss or after a year of holding in my country).

I reevaluate my portfolio pretty regularly, but my goal is to keep my stocks at "set it and forget it" as much as possible. However, if my thesis changes, I don't hesitate much to sell. TTD was one of my biggest winners, for example, but it's no longer in my portfolio. What made me sell in that specific case was mostly Apple's approach to privacy.

I'm only 24, so I tilt towards tech and growth, but I try to keep some balance with stocks like JNJ, LMT, BAC, JPM, and within my ETFs. This is a portfolio I'd be pretty confident to not touch in 10 years.

author: Nosefuroughtto
body:
I find it odd to consider Amazon like Standard Oil. SO derived it’s monopolistic power through acquisitions of rival refineries and distributors; purely horizontal integration, followed by outright price fixing.

Amazon is absolutely massive, but the growth method and diversity of markets they participate in distinguishes them from old trust oriented monopolies. I’m terms of AWS, the majority of growth was organic, and would not have ran afoul of antitrust law back in its hay day, such as when US v. Aluminum Co. of America was prevailing law.

An attempt to break up Amazon by business segment would probably fail due to the shift since the 70’s from Per Se Antitrust violations to the Rule of Reason. They aren’t dominating any given sector to the point that a court could likely prove anti-consumer behavior, which has increasingly become the prime factor.

Online shopping has a fairly rich market with Walmart, Home Depot, Best Buy, wayfair, etc.; physical stores obviously have Walmart and target being dominant; subscription services are still beaten by Netflix and Google, with Disney catching up fast; AWS competes with Oracle, Microsoft snd Google.

Overall I think the justifications for breaking up Amazon are weak in light of the method of growth, the fact that they aren’t shutting out competitors in any given industry right now, and our much more consumer viewpoint focus on antitrust enforcement.

author: HulksInvinciblePants
body:
>Good thing you can share your wisdom then, oh eternal oracle of the market.

Hmmm. I'm don't recall trying to predict when the market will crash and I post quite a bit, when I'm qualified to do so. My advice this time was making users aware of how bad this post was and how illiterates most this sub is. 

>Surely you know more then Dalio, what books have you written?

L. Ron Hubbard and Cosby wrote books too. That's a pretty low bar. 

>Gold is a old-school store of value by definition and as we saw in 2020 (amongst others) a great asset during times of uncertainty and crashes. Buy it during calm times, sell during fearful times.

Yeah, that's not accurate. Gold is not a hedge, its a portfolio diversifier. It's market correlation is 0.02, which is an unattached, positive number...not the large negative correlation you would hope for from a hedge. It did absolutely nothing during the dot-com bubble and probably hurt most investors that held during 2020.

author: aimaguru
body:
Yeah I'm not the oracle for ya when it comes to trying to time the market :)   


I've been mostly right on my directional plays but wrong too many times to count on "oh I'll just sell here and up my position on the way down" or "this is DEFINITELY never going higher than this" (cries in AMC)  


One framework I've seen (maybe rementioned on Fatty's DD) is would you be more upset about selling at X and it runs up to \[price target\] or holding and it dropping to \[your worst case thesis\].   


Personally (my risk tolerance and thesis re: ATOS, not necessarily yours) is that I like the stock enough and am enjoying the IV selling calls enough that, although I'd love a quick 4-10x pop, I'm okay with holding for the longer term, averaging down, and waiting for phase 3 and/or an acquisition down the line.

author: CodeMaitre
body:
ORCL One Year and 6 Month Chart - [https://imgur.com/S6dI2gg](https://imgur.com/S6dI2gg)

It has pretty much made its move, you'd be buying in the "sell" area statistically. You're correct, the buy zone is  always below regression trend (average) line in the middle, so you'd want to snag it if it goes back down to 75-80. Although its true downward potential is the blue -1 deviation line, so 70-73. Deviations change a little bit day to day as more price data is added but right now you'd be buying into an uptrend which is not very safe. You'd basically be betting to get the cherry on top running up to +1 deviations at 88-91.

author: Toys_R_Them
body:
Most of the new growth has been in tech, and tech rarely pays dividends, outside of some stalwarts like MSFT and ORCL.

A lot of those dividend payers are energy companies and REITs, who also underperformed for various pandemic-related reasons.

A portfolio that high in dividends is typically recommended for older people, who need current income and downside protection in case of economic swings, and could care less about potential growth of their portfolio decades from now.

author: OfficialTestikills
body:
I personally invest heavily in Web3 crypto's and crypto projects that help run and keep these crypto's decentralised. 

What's a web3 crypto? These aren't to be confused with junk like Bitcoin that thinks it is a store of value or will become the new financial system, web3 crypto is literally creating the next stage in internet where you don't need to worry about your companies information / personal information / classified documents being stored on a server that is owned and managed by other companies. Web3 splits this up between 100's of validators that all talk to each other and keep this decentralised and secure from attacks. 

There's also ones creating the future of finance. No longer do you need to get bent over by huge interest rates and banks fucking people over whenever they feel like it. DEFI is run by liquidity pools, people like you and I who store our money with the service and as a result get a percentage of the interest rates. These rates always remain low and competitive and go to the people rather than the big banks.

Then you have oracles that power the decentralisation. Oracles gain info from many sources and feed it to the protocol to offer decentralised information. For easy laymans terms, if I wanted a weather oracle, it would gather weather data from 1000's weather stations and news outlets, work out the average forecast and feed that to my protocol. This means my protocol is giving the users the most accurate non-biased information. Just as a high-level. 

So how do you make money from this? Well, let's look at Ethereum just as an example. Every single protect that runs on Ethereum has to pay "gas" fees on each transaction, this is paid in Ethereum. Ethereum already has 1000's of applications including VISA and MasterCard that constantly have a demand for Ethereum in order to operate and pay these gas fees. You as the investor holds the Ethereum they need and this creates supply and demand. Additionally, each time a company pays their gas fees, the gas is "burnt" (meaning Ethereum used to pay for the transaction is burnt) creating deflation. 

Ethereum is just one project, and not one that I personally even invest in that much, but it's one that I'm sure most people have heard of.   
If you want to look at getting some crypto while it's currently on a low and has huge potentially to be the future of a new decentralised internet feel free to use my exchange code. Swyftx is aussie based exchange and you get 20% off fees with my code, plus I get a kick back [https://trade.swyftx.com.au/register/?ref=brentboydskinner](https://trade.swyftx.com.au/register/?ref=brentboydskinner)

&#x200B;

Message me if you want to know more

author: KyivComrade
body:
Good thing you can share your wisdom then, oh eternal oracle of the market. Surely you know more then Dalio, what books have you written? 




Gold is a old-school store of value by definition and as we saw in 2020 (amongst others) a great asset during times of uncertainty and crashes. Buy it during calm times, sell during fearful times.




Dividends is the only one I'd agree with since the dividend will be shrunk or cut as stockprices plummet.
